title: Provide API for dynamically supplying JSON Schemas

title: Remove trailing slash from git URL before inferring repo name

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Fixes: #71722

While cloning a repo from github with a trailing slash works just fine, VSCode fails to infer the repo name correctly, because it starts looking after the last slash. This PR removes trailing slashes before doing that work, so URLs like https://github.com/ioBroker/testing/ have the correct repo name inferred.

/cc @joaomoreno

title: Allow to disable Windows fs.truncate() upon save through a setting
Open all files in a folder by drag and drop in the editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
It would be great if one could drag a folder from the `Explorer` to the `Editor` pane. When this happens VS Code should try to open all files in the folder, instead of displaying the error message `Unable to open 'Folder name': File is a directory`.

In the example below I wanted to open all files in the folder `Home drives quota`. So I dragged the folder `Home drives quota` to the editor on the right and the pop-up came. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10828570/57277678-f04c7200-70a4-11e9-9cf5-4b2089cf3e6e.png)

title: Add shift+ctrl option to editor.multiCursorModifier setting

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
In Xcode multiple cursors is activated via shift+ctrl and clicking. Could that option (or just any recorded modifier combination) be added to the list of options for editor.multiCursorModifier?

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50696995/multi-cursor-editing-in-xcode-10

title: Update workspace configuration before firing onDidChangeWorkspaceFolders event
body:
Starting from VS Code v1.32, when a workspace folder is opened or closed, the following sequence of events is visible to extensions:

1. Update `workspace.workspaceFolders`
2. Fire the `onDidChangeWorkspaceFolders` event
3. Update the workspace configuration (available through `workspace.getConfiguration()`)
4. Fire the `onDidChangeConfiguration` event

I would like step 3 to occur before step 2, so that the new workspace configuration is available to subscribers to the `onDidChangeWorkspaceFolders` event.

title: Edit > Replace / Ctrl-H loses focus

Start with a text file with the following content: one, two, three, four, five The goal is to replace the comma and space between each word with a line break. Therefore, you want to search for ", " and replace it with "\n". 1. Make sure the cursor is at the beginning of the line 2. Type Ctrl-H to open the Replace dialog 3. title: Hitting enter on suggestion doesn't import module
body:
Issue Type: Bug For this example I'll be using React. I have the following components; ```tsx import styled from "styled-components"; type Justify = "space-around" | "space-between"; export const FlexBox = styled.div<{ column?: boolean; justify?: Justify; }>` display: flex; flex-direction: ${props => (props.column ? "column" : "row")}; ${props => !!props.justify && `justify-content: ${props.justify}`} `; export const Flex = styled.div<{ flex?: number }>` flex: ${props => props.flex || 1}; `; ``` When I try to use them inside another component I do get an auto completion with the correct name whilst typing `FlexBox` but when I hit `enter` it doesn't import it (it does complete it), clicking on the suggestion with my mouse does work. Here's a video describing the problem; [https://monosnap.com/file/dqiy5IbunVfW9ExUZqFwusQy7EErdB](https://monosnap.com/file/dqiy5IbunVfW9ExUZqFwusQy7EErdB) edit: It does show up as a quick fix to import it. title: Upgrading a theme currently requires a window reload
body: If you publish an update to a theme, VS Code will download it automatically but not apply the changes until you do a full reload. There is also no button to reload the window in the extension viewlet.

title: Settings dropdown does not work with touch screen

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body: On Windows 10 select the settings of VSCode (via File->Preferences->Settings) and try the change the value of a setting using a system with touchscreen (e.g. Files: Auto Save). VSCode does not respond at all :-(

title: Support file-level snippet variables.
body:
## Scenario
Working on various projects but using a lot of the same tooling between them, I would love to have the ability to specify file-level snippet variables so I could lift the whole snippet file from one project to another and only have to change the app specific strings in one place. 

### Example
I have snippets that automatically pull in the file name to use in stencil tag names and Component names. However, I scope my components with a namespace (e.g. `xapp-button`).

I would like to have the ability to specify the prefix `xapp-` in one place in the file and reference it though a common variable. This would allow my to copy the snippets file and place it in another project, change `xapp-` in one place to, say, `xapp2-`.

I completely realize a global find a replace accomplished this but I can see it being useful far beyond this simple use case. If snippets could reference variables, or other snippets, we could start creating composable snippets that contain other snippets letting us reduce the duplication of code and, when an issue is found or an enhancement is needed, thigs can be changed from a single location instead of all over the file.

Thank you for your consideration of this feature.

title: Proposal: smoother design for error squiggles
body: The error squiggle is very angular in VSCode / monaco. I think a more rounded design would be less anxiety-inducing and would harmonize more with the typography. Zooming in on what I mean Here are some explorations I did at full size: I created a more rounded version of the underline would be a drop-in replacement for [the current SVG pattern](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/editor/browser/widget/codeEditorWidget.ts#L1793): ```svg ``` ```css background-image: url("data:image/svg+xml,%3C%3Fxml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'%3F%3E%3Csvg width='6px' height='3px' viewBox='0 0 6 3' version='1.1' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' xmlns:xlink='http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink'%3E%3Cpath d='M0,2 C1.5,2 1.5,0.5 3,0.5 C4.5,0.5 4.5,2 6,2' stroke='%23D60A0A' fill='none' /%3E%3C/svg%3E%0A"); ``` I didn't see any process listed for UI design, so I though I would bring this up as a feature request. I would be happy to go through the designers for VSCode before submitting a pull request to change it, as they would have more context on why it is this way ---- Usability issues with squiggles for errors are brought up in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/16204, but I think it's outside the scope of this issue

title: Ability to download older extension version from Marketplace
body:
At my current client I'm forced to develop on a Citrix VM that's blocked from Internet access.

So I need to download Visual Studio Code and all extensions on my local machine, copy them to the VM and install them from there.

Currently, the latest German Language Pack extension (v1.34.0) doesn't match the latest VS Code version (1.33.1), so I cannot install:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9283914/57142561-1c25da00-6dbd-11e9-93f6-a006518ee163.png)

So, please add an option to Marketplace to allow for downloads of older extension versions.

body: Extensions website is not mobile responsive. Viewing is as-if on legacy "desktop site"

title: Background tasks with activeOnStart:false shouldn't show problems if beginsPattern isn't matched

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Currently, background tasks where `activeOnStart` is `false` emits problems into the Problems pane, even if `beginsPattern` is not matched by the output. If begin/end patterns do match, then problems are shown immediately after the matching line(s) is output. But if they begin pattern doesn't match, then problems are still shown-- albeit after a few-second delay.

I assume that this behavior is intentional as a fallback if begin/end patterns are missing. But if begin/end pattens are preset but incorrect (which will often be the case when building or troubleshooting task configs) then this behavior makes is really hard to debug the begin/end patterns because you don't know if they're working or not.

Furthermore, the problems that show up in this case cannot be removed until you close and re-open VSCode.  This means you can't tell the difference between a successful iteration of task config and left-over problems from the previous task run. If you're building a new task config, you might need 50+ iterations before getting the all the regexes right. Each iteration requires closing VSCode, reopening VSCode, re-opening the workspace, and re-running the task.  This is incredibly frustrating.

Instead of the current behavior, I suggest that VSCode should not emit any problems if all the following conditions are satisfied:
* `isBackground` is `true`
* `activeOnStart` is `false`
* `beginsPattern` is present (truthy)
* `beginsPattern` is not matched by the task output

Changing this behavior would make it clear whether a begin/end pattern pair is working or not, because if it's not working then no problems will show up in the problems pane.

BTW if you want to see the current behavior with a test repo, here are repro steps: 

1. `git clone https://github.com/justingrant/problem-matcher-cra.git`
2. `cd problem-matcher-cra`
3. `npm install`
4. break the `beginsPattern` in tasks.json, e.g. by replacing "^" with "^xxxxx" at the start of the `beginsPattern` regex and save the tasks.json file
5. run the `npm start` task using the Debug->Run Task... menu

Expected: no problems shown in the Problems pane (because `beginsPattern` doesn't match anything)
Actual: after a few-second delay, one problem is shown

6. Now press CMD+C (or Ctrl+C on Windows) to quit the task. 
7. Break the `beginsPattern` in some other way, e.g. by changing "xxxxx" to "yyyyy". This simulates the normal, iterative process of building a problem matcher where you try different regxes until you get the right ones.
8. Go to App.tsx and comment out this line of code: 
```typescript
const eslintWillComplain = 'foo';
```
9. Save that file, which will trigger a background recompilation. 

Expected: no errors shown in the Problems pane (because we just commented out the only line of code that was causing a problem) 
Actual: the old problem persists, even though we've fixed the problem in code. 

Once that persistent problem is shown, there's no way to get rid of it without closing and reopening VSCode or by running a working version of the task config, which you won't have because you generally only run into this problem when you don't (yet) have a working version of task config!

title: Splitting terminal opens default shell instead of current one

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
- VSCode Version: 1.33.1
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows 10 1809

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a terminal with a non-default shell - e.g. my default shell in VSCode is cmd, so I would open WSL.
2. "Split" the terminal using the terminal menu bar icon, or the key shortcut (default is ctrl+\)
3. The default shell, rather than the current shell.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

Ideally the shell already in use in the terminal should be the one used for the split terminal.
On one level the current behaviour kind of makes sense, but is pretty unintuitive.
Also, with this issue in place, I'm actually not sure how else I can get a split terminal with non-default shell in any other than the first split?

title: Regex pattern to clear all problems of a task owner

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Some compilers or build pipelines (e.g. create-react-app) emit different output if there are no errors vs. if there are 1+ errors or warnings.  This makes it difficult to build problem matchers because start/end patterns need to have both a "errors" and a "no errors" version inside the same regex.

It would be better if there were a new pattern in task config (e.g. `clearAllPattern`) that, if found, would clear all existing problems from the current owner.  

For non-background tasks this would be straightforward-- if the pattern is matched, then clear all problems from the owner and ignore all problems from the currently-executing task until the task exits.

For background tasks, it'd be a little more complicated: 
1) clear all problems from the owner
2) reset the state if it's currently after a `beginsPattern` but before an `endsPattern`
3) wait until the next `beginsPattern` before logging more problems.

As a side effect, this feature would provide an escape hatch for users who want to clear problems by running a task (#50448), because you could create a task with a `clearAllPattern` that always matches.

title: TextEditorDecorators should also be rendered in minimap
body:
How about rendering text decorators in the minimap?  It looks like textmate colorization is applied, but decorators are not.

We'd like to colorize based on EDG parser results.  We're investigating doing colorization programmatically from our extension using text decorators.

title: Enable FileSystemProvider to stat a file as readonly
body: Currently a [`FileSystemProvider`](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#FileSystemProvider) can register as readonly, meaning that every file it provides is opened in a readonly editor. This is nice, but even better if the [`FileStat`](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#FileStat) it returns from its stat() method had an optional `readonly` property. Then I think [this line](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/c1abf7978d59415dcfcf8cfcb15e0ee30c5e45a5/src/vs/workbench/services/files/common/fileService.ts#L206) could easily treat a true readonly value as a signal to set `isReadonly` true. @bpasero what do you think?

title: For long hovers, errors appear all the way at the bottom and require scrolling

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: I'm not sure if this is new, but I'm seeing it a lot lately. When I hover over some code with a red squiggle, if the hover/tooltip has a long description, I have to scroll all the way to the bottom to find the error. I think it would be better if errors/warnings were either at the top, or somehow docked at the bottom of the tooltip, so you don't have to scroll to get to them. Some tooltips a REALLY long and it's a pain. I'm aware of the F8 functionality, I just prefer the tooltips :-)

title: Make scroll bar opaque

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Turn off Word Wrap. 
2. Disable Minimap.
3. Write a long line.
4. The line is visible under the scroll bar.

title: Add a button to open Find All References from Peek References
body: Issue Type: Feature Request While I typically like to use Peek References (and want to keep it as the default for code lens), once it opens depending on the number of items, I'll then often want to "upgrade" the peek to a full Find All References, but it is not convenient to do so. It would be great if there were a button somewhere like below to run Find All References once the peek is open: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/641685/57004802-fa034080-6b9f-11e9-98da-6c1bbd83ec39.png) VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.34.0-insider (473af338e1bd9ad4d9853933da1cd9d5d9e07dc9, 2019-05-01T00:22:05.899Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18362

title: Expose offline/online detection to extensions
body:
Our Atlassian extension relies heavily on an internet connection and when the user goes offline, we need to disable some functionality and enable it when the user comes back online.

Currently, vscode doesn't expose offline/online events to extensions and so we have to use our own polling to do this which is not great.

It would be awesome if vscode allowed extensions to register to receive offline/online events.

title: Feature Request: open Peek References when Ctrl-click is on the symbol in its declaration
body:
Initially this issue was opened in vscode-go extension repo: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/issues/2451

Maintainer (@ramya-rao-a) asked to reopen it here.

By default, with `Ctrl-click` you go to symbol definition, f.e. to a function declaration. When you make `Ctrl-click` on a declared name, VS Code in fact does nothing, which seems counter-intuitive. In most of the cases I need to `Shift-F12` to see the usages of that symbol or if I want to go back from that place after some navigation happened around that symbol.

I think it would be very useful, if when you `Ctrl-click` on a function, variable, or a type name in a place where the symbol is defined, `VS Code` will open a Peek References of that symbol. This would be close to what Goland does by default and what I personally found extremely helpful.
